title: Jazz Legend Miles Davis’ Trumpet Hits Auction at Christie’s
text:
Text size

A trumpet designed and played by Miles Davis, one of the most influential jazz musicians in history, could sell for between $70,000 and $100,000 at a Christie’s auction next month.

The trumpet was made by the Martin Company, which was founded in Chicago in 1865 by German instrument-maker Johann Heinrich Martin, around 1980 to Davis' specifications, according to Christie’s.

The instrument, featuring a deep blue lacquer and gilt crescent moon and stars, with the name “Miles” inscribed on the bell, is one of a set of three colored trumpets designed by Davis. It was acquired by the present, anonymous owner from the collection of jazz guitarist George Benson, according to Christie’s.

The set’s red version has remained in the musician’s family since his death in 1991, while the black one is buried at his side in Woodlawn Cemetery in New York City.

The deep blue trumpet will be offered at “The Exceptional Sale” at Christie’s New York on Oct. 29.

The trumpet features crescent moon and stars. Courtesy of Christie's

“Miles Davis' music has that same magical, transformative power to move us that a great masterpiece of painting or sculpture does,” Becky MacGuire, director of the sale, said in a statement. “His iconic trumpet couldn’t be more perfect for this ‘best of the best’ auction.”

The trumpet is both a fine piece of craftsmanship and marks a crucial moment in Davis’ career. Davis produced many critically acclaimed albums over the decades, from the mid-1940s to the mid-1970s. His 1959 album, Kind of Blue, remains the best-selling jazz album ever.

However, he stopped making music around 1975 due to a combination of exhaustion and drug addiction, and wouldn’t pick up an instrument again in earnest until the early 1980s, which was when the “Moon and Stars” trumpets were created, according to Christie’s.

The trumpet, alongside other highlights of “The Exceptional Sale,” will be open to public viewing from Oct. 24-28 at Christie’s Rockefeller Center galleries in Manhattan.
